description: From French négociant, or its source, Latin negōtiant-, present active infinitive of negōtior, probably via Italian negoziante (“merchant”).

entries.meaning: (now rare, chiefly historical) Someone who conducts negotiations; a negotiator, an agent. [from 17th c.]
examples: Ambassadors, negotiants, and generally all other ministers of mean fortune, in conversation with princes and superiors, must use great respect

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A trader or merchant; a businessman; a financier. [18th–19th c.]
examples: Such was the scarcity of bread, that a French gentleman told me, that, the day preceding the taking of the Bastille, he was invited to dine with a Negotiant, and, when he went, was informed that a servant had been out five hours in search of bread, and had at last been able to purchase only one loaf.
